questions.text: Which of the following vessels is involved in the condition shown below
questions.solution:
Blood supply of Medulla oblongata

  • Anterior spinal artery: This supplies the whole medial part of the medulla oblongata.
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery: This supplies the posterolateral part of the medulla.

Lateral medullary/Wallenburg syndrome:

  • Occurs due to blockage of posterior inferior cerebellar artery.
  • It supplies areas behind the inferior olivary nucleus.
  • Features are:
    • Ipsilateral paralysis of most of muscles of soft palate, pharynx and larynx due to injury to nucleus ambiguous which gives fibres to IX, X and XI cranial nerves.
    • Loss of pain and temperature on same side of face due to involvement of spinal nucleus and spinal tract of trigeminal nerve.
    • Loss of pain and temperature on opposite side of the body due to involvement of lateral spinothalamic tract.
    • Giddiness due to involvement of vestibular nuclei.
    • Damage to inferior cerebellar peduncle, spinocerebellar tracts and part of cerebellum results in loss of equilibrium, i.e. ataxia of limbs on the same side.
    • The sympathetic fibres descend from hypothalamus to cells in lateral horn of spinal cord.
    • As these fibers descend in the lateral part of medulla (which is damaged), there is Horner's syndrome, comprising ptosis, enophthalmos, miosis and anhydrosis.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-4, 9th Edition, Page No - 106, 107

questions.text: Match the following
questions.solution:
• Shrugging of shoulder is done by trepezius muscle.
    • It is supplied by spinal accessory nerve.
  • The lingual nerve is the nerve of general sensation and the chorda tympani is the nerve of taste for the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
    • The chorda tympani nerve is a branch of facial nerve.
    • The lingual nerve is branch of mandibular nerve.
  • The glossopharyngeal nerve is the nerve for both general sensation and taste for the posterior one-third of the tongue.
  • Chewing is done by muscles of mastication.
    • All the muscles of mastication are supplied by mandibular nerve.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-3, 9th Edition, Page No - 77, 80, 88, 93,

choices.text: They retract the scapula along with middle fibres of Trapezius
They elevate the scapula along with fibres of Trapezius
They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity inferiorly
They rotate the scapula tilting the glenoid cavity superiorly

questions.text: Which of the statements given below regarding the muscle shown in the image are correct?
questions.solution:
Muscles shown in image is rhomboidus minor and major muscle

Actions of trapezius:

  • Upper fibres act with levator scapulae, and elevate the scapula, as in shrugging.
  • Upper fibres of both sides extend the neck
  • Middle fibres act with rhomboids, and retract the scapula
  • Upper and lower fibres act with serratus anterior, and rotate the scapula forwards around the chest wall thus playing an important role in abduction of the arm beyond 90 degree.
  • Steadies the scapula.

Action of rhomboids:

  • Retraction of scapula along with trapezius.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page No - 72

questions.text: Patient presents with abnormal sensation in little finger with weakness of medial palm muscles. The most probable site of injury in the image given below is at
questions.solution:
• Medial side of hand is supplied by the ulnar nerve and most of muscles of palm are supplied by ulnar nerve.
  • The ulnar nerve gives off three sets of cutaneous nerves in hand.
  • The palmar cutaneous branch (C7, C8) arises in the middle of the forearm and descends, crossing superficial to flexor retinaculum and supplies skin of the medial one-third of the palm.
  • The palmar digital branches of the ulnar nerve (C7, C8) are two in number. They arise from the superficial terminal branch of the ulnar nerve just distal to the pisiform bone.
    • The medial of the two branches is a proper palmar digital nerve for the medial side of the little finger.
    • The lateral branch is a common palmar digital nerve which divides into two proper digital nerves for supply of adjacent sides of the ring and little fingers.
    • Thus it supplies skin of medial 1½ digits, their nail beds and skin on the dorsal aspects of distal phalanges of medial 1½ digits.
  • The dorsal branch of the ulnar nerve (C7, C8) arises about 5 cm above the wrist. It descends with the main trunk of the ulnar nerve almost to the pisiform bone. Here, it passes backwards to divide into three (sometimes two) dorsal digital nerves.
    • Typically, the region of skin supplied by the dorsal branch covers the medial half of the back of the hand and the skin on the dorsal aspect of the medial 2½ digits.
  • Three nerves are directly related to the humerus and are, therefore, liable to injury-
    • The axillary nerve at the surgical neck
    • The radial nerve at the radial groove
    • The ulnar nerve behind the medial epicondyle
  • As per in image in question the marked areas are as follows:
    • A - Surgical neck of humerus
    • B - Radial groove of humerus
    • C - Medial epicodyle of humerus
    • D - Lateral epicodyle of humerus
  • The ulnar nerve passes behind the medial epicondyle

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-1, 9th Edition, Page No - 16, 17, 89

choices.text: Fundus and body of Gall bladder

questions.text: Anterior relations of third part of duodenum are all except
questions.solution:
Relation of 3rd part of the duodenum:

  • Peritoneal Relations:
    • It is retroperitoneal and fixed. Its anterior surface is covered with peritoneum, except in the median plane, where it is crossed by the superior mesenteric vessels and by the root of the mesentery.
  • Visceral Relations:
    • Anteriorly:
      • Superior mesenteric vessels
      • Root of mesentery
      • Coils of jejunum
    • Posteriorly:
      • Right ureter
      • Right psoas major
      • Right testicular or ovarian vessels
      • Inferior vena cava
      • Abdominal aorta with origin of inferior mesenteric artery
    • Superiorly: Head of the pancreas with uncinate process
    • Inferiorly: Coils of jejunum

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 2, 9th Edition, Page No - 306

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles are supplied by Superior Gluteal Nerve
A. Gluteus medius
B. Gluteus minimus
C. Tensor fascia lata
D. Piriformis
questions.solution:
Superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1)

  • The superior gluteal nerve is a branch of the lumbosacral plexus.
  • It enters the gluteal region through the greater sciatic foramen, above the piriformis, runs forwards between the gluteus medius and minimus.
  • It supplies three muscles, viz. the gluteus medius, the gluteus minimus and the tensor fasciae lata.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume - 2, 9th Edition, Page No - 82
